questions.text: A 16-year-old girl arrives with several swellings and numerous brown rashes. Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas. There are irregularities in her biochemical values. Additionally, she has a past medical record of hypothyroidism. The provided image displays an X-ray of her femur. What is the probable diagnosis from the options provided?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. McCune-Albright syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presentation of several swellings and numerous brown rashes represents café Au lait spots . Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas. There are irregularities in her biochemical values. Presence of past medical history of hypothyroidism, and Shepherd crook deformity of femur in the given image, all point towards the McCune Albright Syndrome .
  • ➤ The presentation of several swellings and numerous brown rashes represents café Au lait spots .
  • ➤ café Au lait spots
  • ➤ Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas.
  • ➤ There are irregularities in her biochemical values.
  • ➤ Presence of past medical history of hypothyroidism, and Shepherd crook deformity of femur in the given image, all point towards the McCune Albright Syndrome .
  • ➤ McCune Albright Syndrome

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was brought by his parents to the clinic complaining of pain in his right hip. An X-ray of his pelvis was taken and is shown below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Osteogenesis imperfecta

questions.text: A patient who used to workout regularly at the gym, gradually developed pain in the hip which is aggravated while squatting. He gives history of regular steroid and creatine use over last six months. There is flattening of femoral head and subchondral cysts were seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) AVN of hip

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Regular steroid is the major risk factor for development of avascular necrosis of the hip. Flattening of femoral head on radiograph is also seen in the avascular necrosis of hip.
  • ➤ Regular steroid is the major risk factor for development of avascular necrosis of the hip.
  • ➤ Flattening of femoral head on radiograph is also seen in the avascular necrosis of hip.

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect about the pathology shown?(NEET PG 2019)

options.label: D
options.text: Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

questions.correct_answer: D. Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) of bone typically manifests as an eccentric lytic lesion in the epiphyseal region of long bones with distinct margins. The mainstay of treatment for GCT is surgical intervention, either through curettage or excision followed by bone grafting, rather than chemotherapy. This surgical approach helps ensure complete removal of the tumor and helps prevent recurrence.

questions.text: What are the different levels of triage in emergency care? (INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: C
options.text: Head neck, thoracic and abdominal triage

questions.correct_answer: B. Immediate, delayed, and minimal triage
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Immediate, delayed, and minimal triage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Triage helps to ensure that patients receive the appropriate level of care based on their condition and the resources available. By prioritizing patients based on the severity of their injuries or illnesses, emergency medical personnel can provide the best possible care to the greatest number of patients in a disaster or emergency situation.

questions.text: Match the Eponym with their fractures.(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-e

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 1. Pilon’s fracture: It is the intra-articular comminuted fracture of the distal tibia. It is also known as Plafond fracture, Tibia Plafond fracture, Distal Tibial Explosion fracture. The high energy axial compression force if the tibia acts as a pestle, driving vertically into the talus.
  • ➤ 1. Pilon’s fracture:
  • ➤ 2. Runner’s fracture: It is the fracture of lower end of the fibula. They are usually the stress fracture, commonly seen in runners.
  • ➤ Runner’s fracture:
  • ➤ 3. Cotton’s fracture: It is the trimalleolar fracture in the ankle i.e., there is involvement of medial and lateral malleoli, and posterior aspect of the tibial plafond (also called as posterior malleolus). This is a more unstable fracture and may be associated with ligamentous injury.
  • ➤ Cotton’s fracture:
  • ➤ 4. Chauffer’s fracture: It is an intra-articular oblique fracture of the styloid process of the radius. It is sustained from a direct trauma like a blow to the back of the wrist or from forced dorsiflexion and abduction of the wrist.
  • ➤ 4. Chauffer’s fracture:

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with headaches for 6 months. She has been taking analgesics regularly. The headache recently increased in severity for 3 days but was reduced on stopping the analgesic. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Medication overuse headache

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Medication overuse headache is characterized by the worsening of headaches due to frequent use of headache medications, and improvement upon cessation of the medication. This phenomenon highlights the importance of managing headache disorders with appropriate treatments and avoiding overuse of analgesics.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the orthopedic clinic with persistent left knee pain and swelling for the past three months. He describes the pain as constant and worsening, even occurring at rest. There is no history of trauma. Physical examination reveals a swollen and tender distal femur with limited range of motion due to pain. An X-ray shows a sunburst pattern and periosteal reaction consistent with an aggressive bone lesion. The tumor is surgically resected, and the gross specimen reveals a gritty, gray-white mass with areas of necrosis and hemorrhage. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Osteosarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteosarcoma is a primary malignant bone tumor common in adolescents, presenting with aggressive radiographic features and characteristic gross pathology. Early recognition and timely intervention are crucial to prevent metastatic spread and improve survival outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following substances can be used for new bone formation in cases of non-union fracture?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bone morphogenetic protein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ BMP helps in bone formation and repair. Thus, for the union of non-united fractures by surgery, it is used as an autograft material.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with bitemporal hemianopia. CT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Craniopharyngioma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A calcified lesion in the suprasellar region suggests craniopharyngioma . It is derived from Rathke's pouch.
  • • calcified lesion in the suprasellar region
  • • suggests craniopharyngioma
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Pituitary adenomas are seen in the sellar region in adults. Macroadenomas are seen as snowman or figure of eight appearance.
  • • Option A:
  • • Macroadenomas are seen as snowman or figure of eight appearance.
  • • Option B: Meningioma is a supratentorial tumor, mainly in the parasagittal region. A classical Dural tail is seen.
  • • Option B:
  • • Dural tail
  • • Option D : Oligodendroglioma is exclusively found in the cerebral hemispheres, most commonly in the frontal lobes. Up to 90% of oligodendrogliomas contain visible calcification on CT .
  • • Option D
  • • calcification on CT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Craniopharyngioma should be considered in pediatric patients presenting with visual disturbances and evidence of a calcified mass in the suprasellar region on imaging. This diagnosis is important due to the potential impact on the optic pathways and pituitary gland function, requiring careful management.

References:

  • ↳ Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 742

questions.text: A child presents with right hip pain and difficulty walking. An X-ray of the hip, shown below, reveals certain abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Osteopetrosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation of hip pain and difficulty walking, along with the X-ray findings of sclerosis and thickening of bones (increased radiographic density), strongly suggests osteopetrosis . Osteopetrosis, also known as "marble bone disease," is characterized by defective bone resorption due to impaired osteoclast function, leading to bones that are denser yet more fragile. This increased bone density is a hallmark of the condition and can paradoxically make the bones more prone to fractures.
  • • osteopetrosis
  • • "marble bone disease,"
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B . Osteopoikilosis - This condition typically presents with numerous small, round, sclerotic bone lesions scattered throughout the skeleton, rather than generalized bone sclerosis.
  • • Option B
  • • Option C . Osteoporosis - Usually presents with decreased bone density, thinning cortices, and increased fracture risk, not increased bone density.
  • • Option C
  • • Option D . Osteogenesis imperfecta - Known for generalized osteopenia, frequent fractures, and bone deformities due to defective type I collagen, not increased bone density.
  • • Option D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteopetrosis is marked by increased bone density and thickness due to defective bone resorption, often leading to pain and fractures despite the denser appearance of bones.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aberrant right subclavian artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An aberrant right subclavian artery is an anatomical variant where the artery arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch and courses posterior to the esophagus, often leading to dysphagia lusoria due to esophageal compression.

questions.text: Painful arc syndrome is seen in:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mid-abduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Painful arc syndrome, a clinical manifestation of impingement syndrome, is observed during mid-range shoulder abduction, typically between 60° and 120°. This condition is often seen in individuals engaging in activities that involve repeated arm elevation, and management may include NSAIDs, corticosteroid injections, physical therapy, or, in refractory cases, surgical intervention to decompress the subacromial space.

questions.text: Counter force brace is used for:(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Tennis elbow

questions.text: Which of the following isn't considered a benefit of USG compared to Mammography? (INICET MAY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable or clinically non palpable breast mass

options.label: B
options.text: Useful in young females with dense breast

options.label: C
options.text: Differentiates between solid and Cystic lesions in the Breast

questions.correct_answer: A. Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable or clinically non palpable breast mass
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable clinically non palpable breast mass

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ultrasound should not be considered a standalone screening tool for non-palpable breast masses or those not detected by mammography. However, it is invaluable in specific scenarios such as evaluating women with dense breasts, distinguishing between cystic and solid breast lesions, and facilitating guided biopsies.

questions.text: A person after sleeping overnight with the arm under his head now experiences paresis but no numbness in the morning. Which of the following is the best explanation for it? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers

options.label: B
options.text: A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers

options.label: C
options.text: A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers

options.label: D
options.text: A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers

questions.correct_answer: C. A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In the above scenario, the patient has developed paresis (partial paralysis) but the pain sensation is intact (no numbness) suggests A fibers involvement as they carry motor, touch, and pressure sensations are most sensitive to pressure changes/compression.
  • • A fibers are myelinated nerve fibers responsible for transmitting signals related to touch, pressure, and proprioception (the sense of one's body position). C fibers, on the other hand, are unmyelinated and transmit slower pain signals. While both types of fibers can be affected by pressure, A fibers are more vulnerable to damage from sustained pressure than C fibers, which are more resistant to compression.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers. - Incorrect. C fibers are unmyelinated and relatively more resistant to pressure compared to myelinated A fibers.
  • • Option A. C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers.
  • • Option B. A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers. - Not relevant to the scenario, as the issue is related to mechanical pressure, not oxygen deprivation.
  • • Option B. A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers.
  • • Option D. A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers. - Also not relevant to the given scenario, focusing on hypoxia instead of the impact of mechanical pressure or compression.
  • • Option D. A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Relative susceptibility -
  • ➤ Relative susceptibility -

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of morning stiffness, along with pain and swelling in her small joints, particularly in the fingers and wrists. She also notes fatigue and difficulty performing daily tasks, such as opening jars or typing. Physical examination reveals tenderness and swelling in the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally. Laboratory tests show elevated ESR and CRP levels, and she is positive for anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies. Which of the following statement is correct regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Biologic agents are first-line therapy and should be initiated immediately upon diagnosis.

options.label: B
options.text: Morning stiffness lasting over an hour is indicative of inflammatory arthritis.

options.label: C
options.text: Imaging findings of joint erosions are required for diagnosis.

options.label: D
options.text: Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) are not effective in early stages of the disease.

questions.correct_answer: B. Morning stiffness lasting over an hour is indicative of inflammatory arthritis.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Morning stiffness lasting over an hour is indicative of inflammatory arthritis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Morning stiffness lasting more than an hour is a hallmark of inflammatory arthritis and helps distinguish it from other joint disorders. Early use of DMARDs is crucial to control inflammation, prevent joint damage, and improve long-term outcomes.

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman comes with a history of Colles’ fracture 6 months ago. Her DEXA scan reveals T score of -2.5. What is the next best step?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Alendronate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alendronate, a drug of class of bisphosphonates is the drug of choice for the treatment of osteoporosis.

questions.text: During the process of conducting a caloric test, what kind of nystagmus should one anticipate when using cold water irrigation?(AIIMS MAY 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side

options.label: B
options.text: Vertical nystagmus towards the same side

options.label: C
options.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side

options.label: D
options.text: Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side

questions.correct_answer: C. Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The caloric test, particularly when using cold water, is designed to stimulate the horizontal semicircular canal, resulting in horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side. This test is critical for evaluating unilateral weaknesses in the vestibular system and helps in diagnosing conditions affecting balance and spatial orientation.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, page No. 45
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, page No. 45

questions.text: Which of the following findings are seen in a high-resolution CT scan of fungal pneumonia?(INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: D
options.text: Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities

questions.correct_answer: D. Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Invasive aspergillosis
  • • HALO SIGN – Multiple nodules with central solid part and haziness around the lesion Seen in immunocompromised individuals with febrile neutropenia DOC – voriconazole
  • • HALO SIGN – Multiple nodules with central solid part and haziness around the lesion
  • • Seen in immunocompromised individuals with febrile neutropenia
  • • DOC – voriconazole
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Kerley lines: Commonly associated with interstitial edema and pulmonary congestion, not specifically fungal pneumonia.
  • • Option A. Kerley lines: Commonly
  • • Option B. Hilar lymph nodes: While enlargement can be seen in various conditions, it is not a specific finding for fungal pneumonia.
  • • Option B. Hilar lymph nodes:
  • • Option C. Pleural effusion: Although it may be present in various lung infections and conditions, it is not characteristic of fungal infections like invasive aspergillosis.
  • • Option C. Pleural effusion:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities on a high-resolution CT scan are indicative of fungal infections like invasive aspergillosis, especially in immunocompromised patients. Recognition of these signs is crucial for the timely initiation of appropriate antifungal therapy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with breathlessness and chest pain. She is a known case of mitral stenosis. Her pulse is irregularly irregular. No thrombus is seen on echocardiography. What can be done to prevent future thrombotic events? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Oral warfarin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with atrial fibrillation associated with mitral stenosis, oral warfarin is the recommended anticoagulant to prevent thromboembolic events.

questions.text: Treatment of open fracture of femur: (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.correct_answer: C. Open reduction and external fixation
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Open reduction and external fixation

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic with persistent lower back pain and stiffness that has been ongoing for the past year. He reports that the pain is worse in the morning and improves with physical activity throughout the day. He denies any recent trauma or injury. Physical examination reveals reduced range of motion of the lumbar spine. X-rays of the lumbar spine and pelvis show fusion of the sacroiliac joints and syndesmophytes along the spine, creating a "bamboo spine" appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Ankylosing spondylitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ankylosing spondylitis presents with chronic back pain, morning stiffness, and characteristic imaging findings such as sacroiliac joint fusion and syndesmophyte formation, leading to a "bamboo spine." Early recognition and management can help reduce symptoms and prevent long-term complications.

questions.text: Most sensitive test for Carpal tunnel syndrome is:(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Durkan’s test

questions.explanation:

questions.text: The image given shows a patient who has undergone total laryngectomy due to laryngeal cancer. Identify the method of voice generation for this patient, as depicted in the provided image.(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tracheoesophageal prosthesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tracheoesophageal prosthesis is a common and effective method for voice restoration following total laryngectomy. It relies on a surgically implanted device that directs air into the esophagus where vibrations are created for speech, significantly enhancing the quality of life for patients who have lost their natural voice box.

questions.text: What is the best imaging study for diagnosis of cerebral infarct?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Diffuse weighted MRI

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Diffusion-weighted MRI is the most sensitive investigation for diagnosis of cerebral ischemia. It is particularly useful for identifying acute ischemic changes in the brain due to its ability to detect diffusion restriction of water molecules in the brain tissue.
  • • Diffusion-weighted MRI is the most sensitive investigation
  • • Diffusion restriction: hyperintense on DWI and hypointense on ADC.
  • • Diffusion restriction:
  • • Diffusion restriction is seen with: Acute stroke Hypercellular tumors Abscess Epidermoid cyst Keratin-Craniopharyngioma/ Cholesteatoma
  • • Diffusion restriction is seen with: Acute stroke Hypercellular tumors Abscess Epidermoid cyst Keratin-Craniopharyngioma/ Cholesteatoma
  • • Acute stroke Hypercellular tumors Abscess Epidermoid cyst Keratin-Craniopharyngioma/ Cholesteatoma
  • • Acute stroke
  • • Hypercellular tumors
  • • Abscess
  • • Epidermoid cyst
  • • Keratin-Craniopharyngioma/ Cholesteatoma
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. FLAIR MRI: Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery (FLAIR) MRI is useful for identifying older infarcts and chronic changes but is less sensitive in the acute phase of a stroke.
  • • Option A. FLAIR MRI:
  • • Option B. Non-contrast CT: While commonly used for initial assessment due to its availability and speed, it is less sensitive in the early stages of a stroke, often not showing changes until several hours post-onset.
  • • Option B. Non-contrast CT:
  • • Option D. СECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT): Typically used to assess for complications or other causes of symptoms but not as sensitive as DWI for early detection of cerebral infarcts.
  • • Option D. СECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diffusion-weighted MRI is the optimal choice for early detection of cerebral infarcts, making it an indispensable tool in acute stroke management. Its ability to show diffusion restriction provides critical information that can influence therapeutic decisions.

questions.text: 3-point bony relationship is maintained in which fracture? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Supracondylar humerus fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The three-point bony relationship of the elbow is maintained only in the supracondylar humerus fracture because this fracture occurs above the bony landmarks associated with the relation.
  • ➤ The three-point bony relationship of the elbow is maintained only in the supracondylar humerus fracture because this fracture occurs above the bony landmarks associated with the relation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman visits her physician for an evaluation of her bone health due to concerns about osteoporosis. She has no history of fractures but reports a decrease in height over the past few years. The physician explains that assessing bone mineral density is crucial to diagnose osteoporosis and prevent fractures. Several imaging techniques are discussed during the visit. Which of the following radiological investigations is NOT used for diagnosing osteoporosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bone scintigraphy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bone scintigraphy is not used for diagnosing osteoporosis as it measures bone metabolism rather than bone density. DEXA remains the primary method for assessing bone mineral density and diagnosing osteoporosis, with other modalities like quantitative CT and peripheral DXA serving as supplemental tools.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations are not used for diagnosing osteoporosis?(INICET NOV 2020) DEXA Bone scan Quantitative CT Chemical analysis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DEXA scan is the investigation of choice. Quantitative CT is a bone mineral density (BMD) measurement technique in which the CT scanner is calibrated using solid phantoms (made of calcium hydroxyapatite, representing various bone mineral densities) placed under the patient in a pad. With this calibration, the Hounsfield units are converted to bone mineral density values. The technique can be used for both peripheral and central BMD measurements, with lumbar spine and hip being preferred locations. DEXA measures the bone mineral density of both the outer (cortical) shell and the inner (trabecular) structure of the bone. QCT, on the other hand, measures only the inner part. Because of this difference, QCT studies of the spine show a lower T-score than a DEXA would.
  • ➤ DEXA scan is the investigation of choice.
  • ➤ Quantitative CT is a bone mineral density (BMD) measurement technique in which the CT scanner is calibrated using solid phantoms (made of calcium hydroxyapatite, representing various bone mineral densities) placed under the patient in a pad. With this calibration, the Hounsfield units are converted to bone mineral density values. The technique can be used for both peripheral and central BMD measurements, with lumbar spine and hip being preferred locations.
  • ➤ DEXA measures the bone mineral density of both the outer (cortical) shell and the inner (trabecular) structure of the bone. QCT, on the other hand, measures only the inner part. Because of this difference, QCT studies of the spine show a lower T-score than a DEXA would.

  • ➤ In CTEV, male children are more affected than females.
  • ➤ In CTEV, male children are more affected than females.
  • ➤ 50% of cases of CTEV have bilateral lower limb involvement.
  • ➤ 50% of cases of CTEV have bilateral lower limb involvement.
  • ➤ There is forefoot adduction and supination in cases of CTEV.
  • ➤ There is forefoot adduction and supination in cases of CTEV.
  • ➤ Ponseti method of conservative treatment gives correction of up to 90%.
  • ➤ Ponseti method of conservative treatment gives correction of up to 90%.

questions.text: A child presents with cyanosis. His chest radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray showing a boot-shaped heart are suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).
  • • TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart disease comprised of four components:
  • • Right ventricular hypertrophy –Boot shaped heart Ventricular septal defect – no heart failure Overriding of aorta Pulmonary stenosis (infundibulum)-Oligemia
  • • Right ventricular hypertrophy –Boot shaped heart
  • • Ventricular septal defect – no heart failure
  • • Overriding of aorta
  • • Pulmonary stenosis (infundibulum)-Oligemia
  • • If ASD plus – pentalogy of Fallot
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ebstein's anomaly: Typically presents with an enlarged and downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, which is not specifically indicated by the features in this X-ray.
  • • Option A. Ebstein's anomaly:
  • • Option B. Transposition of great arteries (TGA): Generally shows a characteristic "egg on a string" sign on chest X-ray, which is not evident in this image.
  • • Option B. Transposition of great arteries (TGA):
  • • Option D. Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC): Would show features like a "snowman" or "figure of 8" heart due to dilatation of the supra-cardiac veins, which is not visible here.
  • • Option D. Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by a distinctive boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray, correlating with the anatomical components of this congenital heart defect, making it a key diagnostic feature in cyanotic pediatric patients .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about Retinitis Pigmentosa? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave

options.label: C
options.text: Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision

options.label: D
options.text: Night blindness is a late feature

questions.correct_answer: D. Night blindness is a late feature
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Night blindness is a late feature

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Night blindness is an early feature of Retinitis Pigmentosa, not a late one. The initial symptoms typically include difficulties with night vision.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented to the emergency department with the sudden onset of severe epigastric pain, she had a history of heart burn and dyspeptic symptoms for past 10 years. On physical exam, she had a temperature of 101.44° F, a pulse of 115bpm and a blood pressure of 125/72mmHg. Abdomen was tender & rigid. What is the likely diagnosis?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Pneumoperitoneum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The presence of free gas under the right diaphragm in the X-ray. This is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum.
  • • C/F: Acute abdominal pain, rigidity, tenderness, guarding MOST SENSITIVE X RAY: CXR-PA erect
  • • C/F: Acute abdominal pain, rigidity, tenderness, guarding
  • • MOST SENSITIVE X RAY: CXR-PA erect
  • • MOST SENSITIVE X RAY: CXR-PA erect
  • • Air under the diaphragm-Right
  • • MOST SENSITIVE Ix: CECT with oral contrast NEXT STEP: Resuscitation with iv fluids, Exploratory laparotomy
  • • MOST SENSITIVE Ix: CECT with oral contrast
  • • MOST SENSITIVE Ix: CECT with oral contrast
  • • NEXT STEP: Resuscitation with iv fluids, Exploratory laparotomy
  • • NEXT STEP: Resuscitation with iv fluids, Exploratory laparotomy
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pneumothorax which represents air in the pleural space, collapsed lung and sometimes mediastinal shift to the opposite side. Presentation is variable and may range from no symptoms to severe dyspnea with tachycardia and hypotension.
  • • Option A. Pneumothorax
  • • Option C. Subdiaphragmatic abscess , there is an infradiaphragmatic localized collection of fluid with gas bubbles or gas-fluid level which has an enhancing wall. It is often combined with elevation of the hemidiaphragm and a pleural effusion.
  • • Option C. Subdiaphragmatic abscess
  • • Option D. Intestinal obstruction on abdominal radiographs show dilated loops of small bowel proximal to the obstruction with visible valvulae conniventes.
  • • Option D. Intestinal obstruction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumoperitoneum is a critical diagnosis identified by the presence of free air under the diaphragm on X-ray, indicative of gastrointestinal perforation, requiring immediate surgical intervention.

questions.text: A young patient with RTA sustained an open fracture of femur which was operated and stabilized as shown below. Identify the fixator.(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rail fixator

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the sports medicine clinic with complaints of knee pain and discomfort in his back over the last six months, especially during and after basketball practice. He mentions feeling "off balance" lately and has noticed that one of his shoulders appears higher than the other. On physical examination, there is an asymmetry of his shoulder heights and a noticeable rib hump on the right side when he bends forward. His spine X-ray shows a left lumbar scoliosis with a Cobb angle of 35 degrees. The physician recommends using a brace to prevent the progression of his spinal curvature. Which of the following braces is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Milwaukee brace

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Milwaukee brace is specifically used for high thoracic and cervical scoliosis curves where other braces may not provide adequate support. It is one of the few braces effective for apex curves above T8, offering rigid support to control curve progression during growth

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with severe back pain, vomiting, and hypotension. CT findings are given below. What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Renal angiomyolipoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The CT image shows a left renal lesion with negative /low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue. This is consistent with renal angiomyolipoma. Clinical findings of severe back pain, vomiting, and hypotension and hematoma around the renal mass are suggestive of rupture. This is known as Wunderlich syndrome .
  • • Wunderlich syndrome
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Renal cysts are homogeneous hypodense lesions.
  • • Option A.
  • • Renal cysts
  • • Option B. Renal cell carcinoma will appear heterogeneous and hypervacular with areas of necrosis.
  • • Option B.
  • • Renal cell carcinoma
  • • Option C. Para pelvic cyst are simple renal cysts that plunge into the renal sinus from the adjacent renal parenchyma. A parapelvic cyst at times may cause compression of the pelvicalyceal system resulting in hydronephrosis.
  • • Option C. Para pelvic cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Renal angiomyolipoma is typically composed of fat, muscle, and blood vessels and appears as a low-attenuation mass on CT scans. When associated with symptoms like severe pain and hypotension, it raises concerns for potential hemorrhage or rupture, emphasizing the need for prompt evaluation and management.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the X-ray? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Patella fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A patella fracture can be identified on an X-ray by a distinct fracture line through the patella, differentiating it from other conditions like hemarthrosis, bipartite patella, and ligament injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following, all are findings of the condition in the below chest X-ray except: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pulmonary venous hypertension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "egg-on-a-string" appearance on a chest X-ray is characteristic of Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA), and pulmonary venous hypertension is not a typical finding in this condition.
